Hello LJ-ers, friends, anon, interested parties, spambots and others. For the purposes of better navigating my journal, please read the mission statement and friending policy below. Mission statement In this journal I have and will continue to post (fan)art, (fan)fiction and the products of other creative endeavours. In putting pen to paper (or finger to keyboard, whichever is appropriate) I intend to better my talents and improve my skills. In posting these works to this journal, not only do I wish to share them with an audience but also solicit suggestions, advice, and general comments. I do not claim to be an expert in any media or topic I put forward. Some subjects you may see in my fanworks are: * Harry Potter, Kingdom Hearts, Naruto, and other books, games and shows, and ideas, quotes and characters from those canons. * Explorations and depictions of life. * Humour, romance, fluff, angst and drama (of the kind to occur in fanworks, not in fandom). * Serious content, such as science, religion, questioning sexuality, gender roles, cultural impacts, et cetera. * Terrible internet sensations. Some topics you will not for the most part see in my fanworks include: * Graphic sex. * Graphic violence (unless it is in good, dark humour fun). * Intelligent design (unless the pursuit is to mock it). As a handful of friends may know, my creative works in the past have not always abided by these guidelines. Thus if you are looking for "Collide", "Reverse!", "Broken", "Bishoujo Shinobi Sailormoon", and some others I haven't remembered, I apologise but will not be publishing them again. Please do not request them. Friending policy None of my creative works are flocked, so you as a user should have no trouble looking for them. I do lock occasionally those entries pertaining to certain individuals and topics, or are not for publishing fanworks. However, this is not my personal journal, so in general entries about my offline life are limited. Do go to my personal f-locked journal if you are that keen. If you do friend me, I will usually friend you back so long as you have been using your journal, and I can understand what you're saying (meaning no netspeak, tongues, spam or advertisements for entries). With that in mind, please comment if you've friended me and several weeks have passed and I haven't friended you. I do try to keep current with my flist, and do read it frequently, but sadly I am a forgetful scribbler and do not check my 'Friend of' list often.

To all who watched, read and commented, I extend my sincerest thanks for enjoying the fest. Before I get on with my submission, I wanted to say a few words about it. I wrote [Wrong Side of Dead] (off-site: over here), a H/D zombie love story. Go ahead and read that again: zombies and love and Harry/Draco. (Truly, in this endeavor my taste is revealed more than what's comfortable.) I wanted to construct a fic that integrated the dynamics of the Harry Potter crew and plot, but cast in a situation cracked with the punches of depreciation and decay that an apocalyptic world might have. To those who wished to shrug off the "idyllic" epilogue, you might also hate what I've done with JKR's cast in an AU-from-HPB world, but you can has zombies. Contrary to what the original prompter wanted (sorry, !), my love of zombies and the undead does not stem from Zombieland, 28 Days Later, George Romero's Night of the Living Dead et cetera, Left for Dead, The Zombie Survival Guide, and whatever other zombie stanchions in pop culture exist. (I must admit, though, that I had picked up Pride and Prejudice and Zombies around the time that I claimed the prompt, but I read most of PPZ after finishing the fic.) Mainly, Halo, Silent Hill, I Am Legend, Urban Dead, and the hearsay of zombie behavior and myth have contributed to my understanding of the zombie assemblage. An additional influence occurred when near the finish line for my fic I learned that academia has pushed for more research in zombie sciences. (Yes, there is an interest in studying zombies but, damnit, I can't find the call for abstracts, so content yourselves with a sample: [zombie apocalypse population modeling].) With that in mind, I constructed a perception of zombies as cooperative individuals who though unaffected by pain, dismemberment, blunt force and whatnot (save a headshot), feel for their fellow zombie and just want to exist; in fact, they are quite sensitive and (dare I say) alive. (This brings to mind Oldboy's theme, "Even though I'm no more than a monster--don't I, too, have the right to live?") However, thanks to Halo and SH, they are still quite terrifying in that they are freshly risen=from-the-grave corpses who pass zombification through death by zombie, and if slighted or have their sights on you, they will chase your ass down regardless of how barricaded your buildings are. Enjoy! Wrong Side of Dead


*^*^*^*^*

PROLOGUE


Proceedings of the International Conference on the Zombie Apocalypse



Opening Address, First International Conference on the Zombie Apocalypse
21 September 2XXX, Oxford, United Kingdom

David E Park

School of Life Sciences, University of W____, L____

The horrific epidemic that swept the United Kingdom nearly a decade ago, the "zombie apocalypse", and its subsequent widespread impacts have brought all of us here today. As is known, the "apocalypse" prepared the scene for the destabilisation of numerous governments, the mass emigration of British citizens and residents to the six continents, and the global financial crisis in the early twenty-first century among other things. However much these consequences have been documented and studied, the overarching question remained unanswered:

How did the "zombie apocalypse", which resulted in a staggering fifteen million fatalities, begin? [Part One] | [Part Two] | [Part Three]

[Prologue] |
PART ONE


Draco wasn't sure if he was awake, asleep, dreaming or dead. Disorientation reigned in his head and spots of light and colour crept inwards in his vision. Yet he was almost certain, thinking past the fog addling his faculties, he could feel some rough cloth under his palms. So, not asleep. When he couldn't blink, Draco lifted a leaden hand and rubbed at his eyes. To his disgust he dislodged gummy sand, and nearly jabbed his eyes in the process. He tried to sit up, but a violent twinge in his skull and the sudden nausea made him lie down again. An exploratory touch revealed a damp bandage wrapped around his head. Draco shuddered - Merlin knew how long he had been lying unconscious, probably in his own blood given how sticky his ear felt, or how he had even been injured.

When the queasiness in his stomach abated enough, Draco discovered that the room in which he found himself was all but barren. The dirty bed and badly-repaired and stained night table were the only furnishings. The previous occupant, or maybe even Draco himself (though he found it unlikely, having no recollection of doing so), had nailed boards onto the wall, probably covering what used to be a window judging by the slivers of light peeking through. The door was chained in Muggle fashion, sealed with a heavy-looking and corroded dead-bolt. Draco was horrified at the grime crawling up the walls from the floor, black paint flung onto an upside-down room so that it crept skywards.

Draco felt as filthy as the room itself; he itched to cast a cleaning spell on himself - but his wand was nowhere to be found. He checked his pockets, the night table, the dingy mattress and the floor, but not once did he see the reassuring gleam of pale hawthorn. Anxiety flooded him - what was he doing in a dilapidated room, removed of his wand and injured? Draco had to discover how he came to be in this condition, and he remembered enough from his experiences in the war that to have any weapon was better than being unarmed. His search wasn't entirely fruitless: he had found a Muggle gun in the drawer. Draco had read about such weapons; they were rudimentary and crude in operation, unlike the sophistication of magical weapons. Still, it had bullets - he found from inspection - and because it appeared so simplistic Draco figured he knew how to use it. He pocketed the gun and gingerly stood.

Untangling the chains on the door was not easy, but Draco's headache was diminishing and he was determined to get the door open. Once past the door, he found that the corridor was much the same as his room. Grey walls etched with dirt and mould surrounded him as he went to the end of the corridor, and down the creaking stairs. Draco emerged into a pub, or what remained of a pub after all its goods were shattered and its patrons removed.

"Hello?"

The air felt thick, like the dust and disuse of the pub were smothering him, and Draco desperately wanted to leave. The fireplace in the corner didn't look like it was connected to the Floo network, and if it was, he didn't see any powder. He avoided the dark stains on the floorboards, an inkling in his mind as to their source, as he walked to the door. He made short work of removing the few rotting boards nailed over the entrance; the barricade was by no means as strong as that of his room, and shoved open the door.

As he had worked at prying away the boards, in Draco's mind the thought had been formulating that perhaps the pub had been abandoned, that the owner had gone out of business, probably from a terrible pub brawl given the condition of the place. When he emerged from the pub, glass crunched under his feet but otherwise the street was silent. Every building he saw looked to be disintegrating from within. Disappointment, and no small amount of panic, filled him. Why was everything he encountered just steps short of ruin? He felt secure that at least he was still in England, though there was no possible reason that the other businesses could be similarly vandalised, unkempt and empty.

A slight breeze and a rustle caught his attention. Draco scanned the pavement and saw across the way a newspaper that had been blown against a Muggle auto resting on flat tyres. He hesitated - even in this deserted area, what if somebody was watching? The paper fluttered again, the almost non-existent wind pushing it onwards, and Draco caught sight of the print. It looked like the layout of The Daily Prophet! He hurried to the Muggle auto, stumbling on the curb. Draco grabbed the edge of the paper -

Bang!

Holes blossomed between the faded newsprint and the force of the gunshot yanked it from Draco's hand. He whirled around -

Bang!

Gunshot pinged off the auto and stung his arm. Draco was briefly thankful that no glass remained in the windows, then ran around the vehicle. Another shot sprayed dust where he had been standing. Draco ducked behind the auto, facing the shop fronts, and withdrew his gun.

"Show your goddamn coward self, you monster!"

By the sound, Draco pinpointed the attacker to be behind and to his left, male and very disturbed. But while he wasn't exactly Godric Gryffindor-brave, Draco thought angrily, nothing he had done while under the Dark Lord's reign merited such mudslinging.

"Stop bloody shooting at me first," yelled Draco. He rose to a crouch and readied his gun, should the attacker identify his location first.

"You talk?" There was faint surprise in his voice.

"Fancy that," Draco retorted. He crept to the rear of the vehicle and dared a peek around the boot. He spotted movement on the first floor of a chemist's, the sun glinting on the jagged glass panes, and fired at the adjacent window.

"Oi!" Draco saw more movement and a flash of blue. His assailant cried out, "What the fuck was that for?"

Draco smirked. "My finger slipped."

"I'll come out and meet with you, if you swear not to shoot at me."

"You as well."

He didn't hear an answer, but Draco waited and watched the building front. In less than a minute his attacker emerged and, with a cautious glance up and down the street, approached the vehicle.

"Here I am," he said, "so you come out too."

Draco had a second to compose himself. He stood, his hand twitching on the gun. "What in Merlin's name are you doing shooting at people, Potter?"

"Malfoy?" Potter's mouth remained open, though he lowered his shotgun. His jeans, shirt and sturdy boots all showed considerable wear, and the satchel tied snugly around his waist sagged as if from carrying too much for too long. "Why're you here?"

"Haven't the slightest," said Draco with an exasperated huff. "Now why - "

Potter flicked his hand at Draco in a shushing motion and glanced up the street. Though Potter's interruption irritated him, Draco paused and followed his gaze. He heard echoes of gunshot and a faint, unidentifiable, cracking sound.

"We had better leave," murmured Potter. He lifted his shotgun as easily as he would a wand and kept it trained in the direction of the disturbance. "It's enough of a risk that we're standing in the open out here."

Without explaining himself, Potter turned on his heel and strode toward the chemist's. Draco briefly weighed his options: he didn't know where he was, how he had arrived there, where his wand could be, and why he had been injured. On the other hand, Potter was wielding a gun and seemed to have his wits about him. So really, Draco thought, he didn't have much choice but to follow Potter to wherever the noble git was going. But, truly, a gun?

"Look sharp." Potter waited at the mouth of the alley between the buildings with a raised eyebrow. As he quickly crossed the street, Draco thought to himself how nice it would have been if he had just barely missed Potter.

"I'm sure you've other former enemies to shoot out, but could you spare a moment and tell me what is going on?" Draco said when he caught up to Potter.

"You really don't know?" Potter looked incredulous, and after giving Draco a once-over continued, "You've some head trauma, I see. Probably amnesia or similar. You should have that looked at."

Maddeningly, after his amateur diagnosis Potter headed down the alley. Draco ground his teeth and exhaled, trying to control his frustration as he followed on Potter's heels. He was determined to remain calm, even though Potter was apparently doing his best to play big, dumb hero (again).

"Maybe you can explain while we... reach a dead end?"

Potter fumbled in the satchel on his hip, and Draco had the moment to appreciate just how ludicrous his entire situation was. In only minutes he had progressed from waking wandless and injured in a depreciated room, to being shot at and then helped (or misdirected, given the dead end) by his former classmate and rival. Draco thought, what kind of world did he wake up to, and how could it have so changed?

"D'you need a hand up?"

Potter's voice cut into Draco's brooding, and he shifted his attention. Potter had withdrawn a rope from his satchel, and had flung one end up to a window on the second floor. Potter had knotted another cord on the rope for some unknown purpose, leaving a generous amount before him, and had his other hand out to Draco.

"Where are we going?" Draco eyed the rope's path up the wall. "To that window? Potter, where's your wand? Just because I haven't mine - "

"Shh!" His eyes darted around, searching and wary. "Here, hold still."

Draco watched with mild fascination as Potter attached a clip to the lead of rope in front of him, and fastened two cords like his own beneath it and on it.

"See?" Potter moved the clip up the rope a hand-span, but when he tried to yank it down it refused to budge and tensed the rope. "You'll ascend like this."

"I'm not sure," said Draco, tenderly touching his wrapped head, "I mean, I might have some trauma like you said."

"I'll be beneath you, in case you slip, but it's only the second floor."

Draco saw he wasn't going to change Potter's mind, and reluctantly took the clip from the outstretched hand. Draco mimicked Potter's position in front of him, the looped cord around his palm and the clip in his other hand.

Potter startled Draco when he spoke almost in his ear, "Move the clip and prusik up the rope, jump and put your feet on the wall. Then repeat, taking a step forward."

Draco muttered only, "Just like you were born on a broom, I bet you teethed crawling up walls."

"I'm not Spiderman," said Potter with a chuckle.

Draco couldn't ponder that statement - he was following Potter's instructions to the best of his abilities, to fight gravity and force his weakened muscles up the wall. The first jump had him bending nearly in half, as Draco was unable to keep his abdominal muscles taut. He clutched to the rope as his shoes - quality Shortsnout hide boots, if his appraisal was correct - skid on the stone.

Potter shoved at his back and muttered encouragingly, "Keep your back straight, don't rely on your arms to hold you up, and remember, one foot in front of the other. If you fall I can't catch you, but it's only a short distance."

He was right, to Draco's genuine astonishment. The climb became easier once Draco had his back straight. ("Posture, Draco," his mother's voice reminded him in a sudden memory.) The clip, too, made using the rope not as difficult. The other cord, Draco found, was like a secondary grip - he couldn't pull it over the clip, like he would climbing hand-over-hand up a rope without mechanical assistance, but it was another valuable handhold that kept him from plummeting to mild injury.

Draco reached the top, but realised quickly that the clip wouldn't make it past where the rope met the sill. He used his other hand to grip the inside of the window, then pulled up his leg with some effort and clambered over the window sill. Draco straddled it for a moment and briefly saw the height that he had climbed. It was a good thirty feet, and he climbed it without magic! He then fell unceremoniously onto the floor, narrowly missing the grappling hook that was holding steady the rope. From his position on the dusty floor, Draco saw Potter climb through the window and pull the rope after him.

"For a moment I thought you were going to fall," said Potter. He folded the arms of the grappling hook and wound the rope in a coil, but glanced at Draco with an expression he couldn't read.

"You underestimate my capacities. Though, the thought of taking you down had crossed my mind," Draco answered. He sat up and found that his arms and legs didn't hurt as much as he thought it would. Draco wasn't even out of breath, though his head still ached. And his hands were sore from gripping the rope; he noticed and instantly comprehended why Potter wore fingerless gloves.

Potter tucked the rope and other equipment into his satchel. "We've some distance more to go." He speculatively eyed Draco and added, "D'you think you can make it?"

"As long as it's not on the tenth floor." Draco stood and brushed off the dust. After Potter shook his head, he walked past Draco to a window on the other wall.

From the chemist's building they leapt across to a flat, went up a musty stairwell to the roof, used the rope again to cross the building - and then, Draco lost track of where they had come from. Potter was leading him on a dizzying and acrobatic tour across the city, going from rooftop to open windows and quite infrequently to street level. Draco ascertained they were avoiding the road, but why that was so he couldn't reckon since all the autos he saw were immobile and decrepit.

Draco also noticed that as they continued the buildings were spaced closer together, and that he was recognising more and more of where they were. But Potter wasn't dallying, so Draco didn't get the chance to question him until they paused in a decrepit office tower.

"Are we in London?" whispered Draco.

Potter was peering out of a window and didn't turn when he answered.

"Yes."

The foreboding feeling that had been nagging him since a couple buildings back made Draco swallow. It was hard to believe that the city was perilous and unpopulated, but he had seen with his own eyes the signs and he wasn't yet about to doubt Potter's caution. Draco bit his lip as Potter finished scanning the outside and faced him.

"We're almost there." He had the rope and grappling hook ready in his hands, and in his eyes was an unusual sobriety. "It's critical that we do this as stealthily as possible. Follow my moves exactly, and watch my hand signals."

Draco raised an eyebrow. Potter was again asking that Draco place all his trust in him - nay, he expected it. Suddenly weary of fighting what seemed inevitable, Draco said only, "I demand an explanation once we arrive, at wherever 'there' is."

He gave a short nod and began feeding the rope out of the window. Draco thought to ask if they couldn't use the stairs, but Potter was fastening clips and cords again to the rope.

"Watch." Potter made a show of looping the cord around his midsection and holding the lower end of the rope in a tight grip at his back. "We're going to abseil down. The stairs've been jeopardised." He held the other end with his left hand in front of him and mimed slow steps, like what Draco did climbing up the wall.

While Draco understood what Potter had planned for them; from all their rope-working his palms were red and stinging. "D'you happen to have another pair of gloves?"

"Oh." Potter sheepishly shrugged his shoulders and added, "Sorry but I've only this pair. Well, here." Potter quickly removed his left glove and gave it to Draco. "You'll go first - once we're out on the street I wouldn't be able to help you much, anyway."

The idea made Draco uneasy, but he nodded anyway, which was what Potter seemed to expect.

With Potter's help, Draco had the cord looped around his waist in some special fashion, for security he figured. Draco took the 'lower' end of the rope in his left hand, held it at his back, and gripped the 'upper' end of the rope in his other hand. He stepped onto the sill, gazed down the wall and let his foot slide off the top and onto the side. But upon seeing the long drop beneath him, fear overwhelmed Draco and he grabbed the rope in front of him with both hands.

"No!" whispered Potter, leaning over the edge to look down at Draco. "You have to keep your hand behind your back!"

"Lunatic!" Draco retorted. Every instinct told him to hold onto the rope. "Couldn't you have picked an easier route?"

"Work your hands in concert," instructed Potter with a worried tone. "Your lower hand makes the slack in the rope, and your upper hand acts as a check. Make it a smooth descent - I know you can do this."

Though he was proving to be quite unlike his previous self, Potter definitely sounded like he knew what he was doing. That, and the visible but odd concern Potter showed, pulled Draco out of the fear. I have to get through this, he thought. He managed to get his hands and the rope in the same position as before, then, keeping his arms rigidly bent, he untensed his grip slightly. He slid a little down the rope and down the wall - but it wasn't the uncontrolled descent he had anticipated. Draco repeated that performance a few more times, each consecutive drop a little longer, until he reached the bottom. When his scuffed boots touched concrete, Draco released the rope with shaky, tingling hands.

With only the whir of rope passing through his hands, Potter landed softly beside him. He got the grappling hook released, looped the rope in his hands, and beckoned to Draco to follow. They darted across the road and onto a sloping ramp, Potter periodically checking their surroundings. Draco saw beyond the ramp a small garden bounded on one side by aged, moss-covered stone and the other by a discoloured, cracked wall. The ramp sloped to the garden, and they cut through it to reach the wall. Potter led Draco around the corner to the rear of the large building it supported, before stopping.

Potter had the grappling hook up the wall, and then they were climbing to the top floor.

"See, wasn't so bad." Potter cracked a smile as he tucked the rope and hook into his satchel. Draco wanted to be angry at Potter, wanted to feel like verbally flaying him, but strangely he was only relieved. He reckoned that they were at their destination, for Potter even took off his glove. Draco did similarly and returned it, feeling inexplicably awkward.

"So, about that explanation..." Draco trailed off, hinting for Potter to pick up.

Potter brightly said instead, "The medic should have a look at you, that head trauma and such. You're not feeling poorly, are you?"

"Not really." Draco followed Potter as they walked through the corridor. Wall exhibits of artefacts and placards were covered with dust and cobwebs. They entered a room just ahead, which displayed unearthed skulls and fragments of past civilisations.

"I found a person," called out Potter as they turned the corner. Following him, Draco saw that they weren't alone.

"Harry!" A young woman who sat on a table, a map and other objects before her, uncrossed her legs and came over to them. She looked harried and ill-rested, but a tense smile bloomed on her face as she approached. Then Draco caught her gaze. "Draco Malfoy?"

Nearly as surprised to see Hermione Granger but unwilling to show it, Draco replied with a grimace, "In the flesh."

"I found him by King Street," said Potter as he and Granger briefly hugged. "Where's Chickering?"

"In Roman, as always." Granger broke eye contact with Draco to scan him, her lips pursed. "That wound doesn't look fresh."

Potter answered, "That's why I brought him." To Draco he said, "Chickering's our medic. She'll evaluate you."

Draco felt Granger's eyes on him as they went to the adjacent room. Potter brought Draco to a dark-skinned woman sitting on an antiquated examination table. She and the table, though it was a relic, were also out of place among archaic busts and artefacts.

"Could you have a look at Malfoy?" greeted Potter.

"I'd wondered if we were going to see you this arvo." Chickering set down the well-used medical text she had been perusing and vacated the table. "Have a seat. Malfoy, was it?"

Relieved of Draco, Potter walked back to the main room. Draco felt a momentary spike of anger at his abandonment, but pushed it down and focused on what the medic was doing. "Yeah. You're a Healer?"

Chickering snorted as she probed the dressing. "I'm a doctor."

Draco realised with alarm that the medic was, in fact, a Muggle. He reflexively flinched, but Chickering ignored it.

"The blood's dried, obviously." She took a white, almost threadbare cloth and dampened it with water from a cooler next to the table. Then Chickering held the wet cloth firmly against Draco's head on the right. "Hold this. When were you injured?"

"I don't remember." Slowly Draco felt dampness creep through the dressings - it felt odd, to say the least, but not that bad. And the cool cloth felt wonderful in his abused and reddened palm. He peripherally saw Chickering move around to the opposite side, scissors in hand. "I woke up a short while ago, but before that I... I don't recall much."

"And Harry found you?" Snip, snip, and Draco felt the dressings loosen around his head, but he thought the dried blood still caked them together over his wound. She's just going to rip them off, he dreaded.

"Yes."

Chickering was at his right again, and she pushed Draco's hand. With unexpected tenderness she peeled away the damp dressing, and let out a soft sigh upon seeing Draco's head.

"This is better than I'd been thinking," Chickering admitted. She dampened another cloth and dabbed at the wound. "For a moment, your amnesia, the head trauma... I had thought maybe you'd been attacked. But it just looks like post-traumatic retrograde amnesia - perhaps you were clumsy or such."

Though her ministrations were gentle, twinges resounded through Draco. He said, gritting his teeth, "Attacked?"

Chickering rolled her eyes and replied, "By the undead, of course."

When he returned to the museum from his regular excursions into London, Harry sometimes wondered what the previous caretakers would have made of their institution in its current state. Months ago most of the proud lettering had fallen off the outside walls, and unchecked weeds and moss grew up from the garden, the latter crawling up the broken concrete. (Harry had recovered the fallen letters and stored them in the museum's front desk, just in case.) The only maintained parts of the building were the exhibit halls they had taken as their 'base', and the barricades on the doors, lower floor windows and any other opening to the outside. On this most recent return Harry saw that somebody had taken off some of the rotting planks on the street-level entrance and hammered on new planks. It heartened him to see how people, his friends, persevered in this mostly abandoned city.

After Harry had deposited Draco into Chickering's capable hands, he returned to the corridor where he found Hermione and Ron lowly conversing. Ron's eyes and mouth, Harry saw with amusement, were getting wider as Hermione spoke. They looked up at the same time when Harry approached.

"How is he?" asked Hermione.

"Dunno." Harry felt a little abashed under her critical glare. She had expected him to stay with Malfoy, but though Harry was fine bringing him to their base, he wasn't going so far as to hold his hand while Chickering treated him.

"Malfoy?" Ron scratched his head. "Really?"

"Harry's been on his feet," reminded Hermione. She took Ron and Harry by the elbows, and led them to the common room.

Along with Hermione, Ron and Harry, there were other wizards and witches in their force, though none of them of their age group. The Tilletts, wiry and friendly both of them, were an older couple who had lost their son and daughter-in-law last year and were determined to survive and locate their grandchildren. Like the Tilletts, Miles Blackleaf - a former Ministry employee - had been only loosely acquainted with the Weasleys. The other wizards and witches Harry hadn't met before joining the base, but they all got along. Chickering wasn't the only Muggle with them, though Harry more keenly appreciated her skills. Their non-magical allies included a father-daughter pair of engineers, a school teacher, and an architect.

Blackleaf and the engineers were talking over improvements to the museum's defences when they entered. They waved and acknowledged Harry's return but didn't pause in their conversation. Harry and Hermione took the other couch, and Ron perched on the armrest by Hermione.

At Ron's inquiry, Harry related where he had explored and how he had eventually found Malfoy. Hermione furrowed her brow when Harry briefly mentioned exchanging gunfire with Malfoy, though Ron sniffed and nodded.

"This is rather unusual," said Hermione when Harry finished. She brushed some dust off her jeans as she thought out loud. "When you scanned the area, he was standing in the middle of the road. Malfoy seemed disoriented at first, but kept up with you. You didn't ask what happened to him?"

"No."

"It wasn't like he and Malfoy could just chat," came Ron to his defence. "But you're sure he wasn't contaminated?"

They discussed the details some more, then Harry, feeling that they had wrought over every angle of the story for now, had asked about the improvements and happenings since he had left at sunrise. Ron was relating how Rachael and Gordon, the engineers, had argued over the best angle for the planks when Malfoy entered the room.

"Hey." Out of concern for Malfoy, whose white face and taut lips spoke of Chickering's treatment, Harry stood and let him take his seat.

"How are you feeling?" Hermione shifted to face Malfoy. Ron looked like he had swallowed a terrible-tasting Bertie Botts bean.

"I've experienced worse."

Harry didn't miss how Malfoy forced his hands to relax on his knees. He must be hurting, thought Harry, and he felt some of that earlier guilt return.

"You didn't see anybody else?" asked Ron in a neutral tone. "No one was with you, Malfoy?"

"I was alone."

Harry said, "But that doesn't mean there isn't anybody else out there."

"Come on." Ron sighed with exasperation and stood. "You've got to face facts, mate. It's been a year since the quarantine, and - "

"And if I hadn't been looking, I wouldn't have found Malfoy." Harry resisted the urge to cross his arms; he had no reason to feel defensive, and he didn't want to leave any crack for Ron to find.

"Harry's been making regular reconnoitres," Hermione explained quietly to Malfoy, "hoping to find others who're resisting the undead."

Ron said nothing, though he looked like he was holding in his opinion. He placed his hands on the arm of the couch and rested his weight on them.

"Is there anywhere I can lie down?" interjected Malfoy. His face was blanched, but didn't reveal anything else.

"The barracks." Harry jumped at this opportunity and said, "I'll show you."

They had converted the farthest exhibit hall for sleeping. The two bunk beds were requisitioned from the Armed Forces display, and in scavenging from other buildings they had managed to find cots, blankets and other bedding. When Harry had departed that morning the Tilletts had been on sentry duty; as he and Malfoy entered, he saw that they and their replacement, the school teacher, were sleeping, along with a few others.

"You can have this cot," Harry whispered, pointing to his own neatly-made bed. Pity made him give up the cot; otherwise, Malfoy would have had to sleep on a pile of blankets and a thin pad.

With a slight bob of his head Malfoy sat on the cot. He seemed to deflate, as if suddenly the strength that had seen him through the wall climbs and Chickering's treatment had been drained from him. Harry turned to go, but Malfoy's quiet voice stopped him.

"When I wake up, you'll provide the details as to how..."

Harry glanced over his shoulder. The fresh, white dressing on his head brought out Malfoy's pale skin, and though his eyes were tired he had a determined set to his face and shoulders.

"Sure. I'll be asleep shortly, to take the 2 a.m. watch. You can join me."

Harry left as Malfoy made himself comfortable on his cot. Though Harry knew he should have turned in as well, his mind was roiling so much with thoughts that he was sure he wouldn't have been able to sleep just yet. Avoiding the common room, Harry headed for the washroom.

Scrubbing his face, Harry pondered the first and most pressing thought: What was Draco Malfoy doing in London? Neither Harry, Ron nor Hermione could remember seeing Malfoy anytime after the quarantine had been imposed on the city, much less the island. Not only that, but most of the witches and wizards who had chosen to stay and fight the tide of undead maintained in contact with each other.

"'Allo, Harry," said somebody as they entered. Harry squinted at the mirror, but he didn't need his glasses to recognise the architect's voice. Harry returned the greeting, and after the architect washed his hands and left, resumed his train of thought. For Malfoy to have stayed in London - if that was the case - since the quarantine without a mention of him in anyone's news, was really... unusual, to say the least. It was almost as if -

No, thought Harry as he took the towel hanging nearby off its hook. He pressed it tightly to his face, feeling the matted terry rub his cheeks and nose. There was no way Malfoy was a zombie. It was plain fact: mortal attacks led to transformation within a day, and Malfoy's wound was older than that. And, Harry further reasoned, Malfoy exhibited none of the symptoms.

After drying his face and neck, Harry replaced his glasses and briskly wiped the rest of his body. Harry smelled his favourite meat cooking, and couldn't help but grin as he followed the scent. In his opinion, one of the few bright sides in this mess was the frequency of Spam at meal times.

"Ugh." Hermione crinkled her nose and pressed her lips together in a moue. Harry shoved half the slice he had picked up from the serving plate into his mouth.

"Mmm," said Harry around his mouthful. The salty, unique taste ricocheted around his taste buds as he chewed the gel-like meat. He shared a grin with Ron, who had pink crumbs drop from his teeth.

"Do you know what they put in this?"

Harry chuckled to himself at Hermione's oft-repeated lament. He knew what was in it (as he had been urged many a time to read the tin), but that didn't make it any less delectable. Before she could continue, he took another couple of slices and a cup of tinned fruit and left for the barracks.

The sun was touching the horizon, he saw when he nudged aside the drapes on the room's one unbarricaded window. Nibbling on his slices, Harry waited and watched the sun drop below and the sky darken above, the soft breathing and snores of his comrades as accompaniment. He thought back to other sunsets like this one, standing vigilant in this same room and in the barracks of other safe houses. Faintly, he recalled twilights at Hogwarts and the camps he, Hermione and Ron had made after sixth year. The sunsets he saw in those years were some of the most nerve-wracking, for he had had no idea if they would still be alive come morning, but some were also lovely to behold and put out of his mind his frivolous worries.

If Malfoy were awake now, thought Harry with a quick glance to make sure he wasn't, he would have scoffed at how... sentimental I'm being, and hexed me probably, if we were back at Hogwarts. With a tiny sigh, Harry finished the Spam and fruit and walked away from the window. He pushed together some unused blankets on one of the thin pads until he was satisfied he wasn't going to be sleeping as good as on the floor. Then Harry removed his satchel and shotgun, placed them beside him at the head, and lay down.

He'll do fine, thought Harry of Malfoy, taking off his glasses and tucking his arm under his head. Harry observed that Malfoy had even put his gun within arm's reach. He thought with growing difficulty about how Malfoy could have acquired a gun and how he knew how to use it - but in seconds, Harry was asleep.

Draco woke to a swift, but gentle, tapping on his shoulder. When he opened his eyes, next to him a dark figure outlined by dim light towered over him, his glasses reflecting the light from the far corridor.

"Watch duty," whispered Potter. For moments, Draco was perplexed - what was Potter doing there, and why were they going on watch? Then he saw the 17th century relics that had been pushed to the sides of the room, and remembered. Draco quietly got out of bed and trailed Potter out of the barracks/exhibit, the gun uncomfortable in his belt.

"The washroom's ahead," said Potter in a low voice as he pointed down the corridor. "We can grab a bite in the common room - I'll meet you there."

In the museum's restroom, Draco checked his dressing. Chickering's medical skills were not bad, considering she was a Muggle. He flushed his face with water, but decided to wipe down the rest of his body, too. He had been so tired the night before that he had gone to sleep feeling the grime on his skin and not giving it another thought. When he was finished, Draco tossed several dirty, pink-pigmented towels in the trash.

Standing at an antique table, Potter was pouring steaming liquid from a pot. Draco, coming around to observe, saw that he had prepared two plates with some food Draco didn't recognise, and had put on, or reheated, coffee. Potter took a mug and plate, and Draco the remainder, and they took spots on the couch farthest from each other, plates balanced on their knees and mugs on the floor.

"What is this?" Draco pointed to the frankfurter-like pieces on his plate.

"Vienna sausage." Potter drank his hot coffee; Draco tried to do similarly, and nearly burnt his tongue.

"This - this is how you live?" said Draco with incredulity. "You, the m - Granger and Weasley - how long has it been like this?"

"Nearly a year. We've still got a good supply of tinned goods." Seeming not to notice Draco's near slip of the tongue, Potter chewed a mouthful of meat with an air of thoughtfulness and swallowed before continuing. "Occasionally they airlift supplies to us."

"They?"

Potter faced Draco and answered, "You really don't remember anything? How far back does your amnesia go?"

Slowly Draco combed through his memories. He knew Potter, that was certain, and Weasley and Granger. He remembered the last time he had seen them was - Easter time, in his seventh year. Draco shuddered as he recalled Bellatrix torturing them, and the fear that pervaded his breath and thoughts that entire time. But after the holidays...

"Easter holiday at the Manor," Draco replied as he pushed away the remnants of fear. "When... you know."

Potter covered his grimace with a bite of the sausage. "Yeah. That was over two years ago."

Shock made Draco mute, and he stared. Yes, Potter was definitely grown from the scrawny, bruised prisoner in the Manor. With food, all that activity from scouting the streets, and time, Potter seemed to have recovered lost weight and gained the muscle that Quidditch, though a gruelling sport, had never built on his short frame. When Draco had looked in the mirror he hadn't noticed any changes in his own face, but he wondered if Potter was thinking the same of him.

Potter seemed not to dwell too long on those thoughts and said, staring at his mug, "I was so close to defeating Voldemort."

Faintly surprised, Draco didn't flinch hearing the name; he distantly remembered the terror associated with the name of the Dark Lord, but it felt like the scar had healed over.

"I had... done what I'd needed to do to stop Voldemort, nearly killing myself in the process and countless others." Draco met his sideways gaze as Potter added, "You were there, in the final battle."

Draco opened his mouth to ask, Whose side was I on? But he held his tongue upon seeing Potter's fraught expression. Anyway, it didn't matter to which faction Draco had finally aligned with, if this was how it had ended.

"Then they appeared. The zombies, or as Hermione and Chickering call them, the undead. They swarmed and overwhelmed Voldemort and the other Death Eaters at the final battle, killing them and... and feasting." Potter closed his eyes and inhaled deeply. "It was horrible. I'd never have wished that on any enemy. Voldemort was to be punished at the hands of those who'd suffered, not murdered.

"At first we were wary and unsure - Hermione thought they were Inferi, but I knew they weren't." Potter grimaced. "Some witches and wizards celebrated and claimed that the undead were Voldemort's victims, recent casualties of the war, and that it was magical retribution. But it wasn't so simple."

After a prolonged silence, Draco impatiently prompted, "And?"

"The zombies retreated from the scene, and we began to clean up the mess of the magical world. We had a new Minister, too, and I had plans - but, then, just as we stopped waiting for the next shoe to drop, the zombies attacked." Potter turned the mug in his hands, his coffee long cold. "They can smell magic."

Draco gasped. "What?"

"That's how they targeted Voldemort. The zombies could sense his magic, and the magic of the Death Eaters, and attacked them first. Then they went after any active witch and wizard." Potter quietly tacked on, "Accidental magic users were... they were just that vulnerable, I..."

Draco could imagine - a young child, to the delight of her parents floating her doll in a magic-run household, would have been as transparent and appealing to the zombies as mice to owls.

"After the contagion spread to the continent, the international wizarding community was able to pinpoint England as the source, just by process of elimination. The country was put under quarantine, and contact with European witches and wizards was limited."

"How did the Muggles come to find out?"

"Zombies attacked Muggles too," said Potter, "more like 'ravaged' them. But at least the attacked and killed Muggles remain dead - I've seen too many familiar faces lunge and attack us than I care to consider. The Ministry felt it was in our and their best interests to assist them, but when Muggles learned that zombies were attracted to witches and wizards, many shunned or turned against us."

Draco said, aghast, "What about the Centaurs? The goblins? The other members of the magical non-human folk?"

Potter shook his head slowly. "They retreated underground, we think. We haven't been able to locate any former allies. Even the house-elves vanished."

"I bet Granger's pleased - a bit of independent thinking, there," scoffed Draco.

"Give her - give us all another chance, Malfoy," Potter scolded. "We accepted you into our base, and we can just as easily turn you out."

Fury and anxiety warred in Draco's mind. How dare Potter claim the moral high ground? It wasn't like Draco begged to come; Potter more or less demanded Draco follow, with nary an explanation until now. More importantly, what if nobody wanted him there? Was there still the old animosity between him and Granger and Weasley? What if the other wizards and witches bore a grudge against him because of his family?

"Don't worry." Potter, perhaps perceiving something in Draco's face, sounded tired, but he stood up with a vigorous attitude. "Nothing you've done would merit a dismissal. Unless we don't go on watch like we're supposed to."

Just steps behind Potter, Draco scolded himself for wearing his heart on his sleeve, and as much for being relieved by Potter's words. Really, there was no reason for him to seek comfort in what Potter said - Draco was a model... well, member of the force, if that was what he was now.

For the next four hours, they walked the two floors of the museum, checking the barricades and scanning the dark streets of London from the windows and roof. Draco occasionally lingered to wipe a placard of its blanket of dust and read the description for an item that was often not beside it. Potter had said that the more obstructing displays had been dismantled and stored on the ground floor. Draco imagined how the museum must have looked before the zombies appeared - he might have even liked it.

Near the end of their shift, Potter led him to the roof with a thermos of coffee, a tin of preserves and stale crackers. A brilliant sun rose over the discarded city, purple and orange with pink clouds that cushioned the crumbling towers. Though he sat not five feet from Potter, eating from the same share of food, in the brightening dawn Draco felt very alone and small, very displaced.

Shortly after dawn, Draco and Potter woke the next pair to go on watch. Draco lingered by the entryway and watched as Potter assembled his kit, the satchel that he had carried yesterday . He then led the way to the base's armoury and showed Draco how to make his own kit. When they returned to the common room, Draco had sturdy trainers (though he was loathe to relinquish his dragon-hide boots), gloves, flares and sundry other items Potter claimed would be useful.

They met Granger and Weasley for breakfast. Draco crinkled his nose at the sulphurous smell of powdered eggs, but took slices of the strange pink meat, tinned yams, and a mug of the syrupy coffee. He lingered with his plate and mug; the others had claimed most of the seats in the common room, but the couch Potter and his friends had occupied the previous afternoon was empty. Draco met Potter's eyes, and Potter nodded his head to the couch; relieved, Draco went to it, to be followed by the other three.

"That's Spam, Malfoy," informed Granger once they were seated, she to his right. Weasley sat on the armrest beside her; Potter had pulled over a stool and sat in front of him and Granger. With an inscrutable expression Granger added, "Do you know what Spam is?"

Puzzled, Draco poked and sniffed it. "A Muggle recipe, judging by your awareness of it. It's meat - not anything weird, though, right?"

Granger, her brow furrowed at Draco's slight, then recited a list of meat products that made his eyes widen with each new animal.

"It's mostly ham," said Potter quickly, seeing his recoil. "Spiced ham, they call it."

Weasley coughed. "Or 'something posing as meat'. You ought to try it - it's fantastic."

Draco cut a tiny piece and licked it. Then he chewed. Granger had a tight-lipped, eager expression as she observed his reaction; Potter and Weasley had exchanged looks, but had continued eating.

He swallowed and with delicious gratification pronounced, "Not bad."

Granger sniffed and speared a yam, obviously displeased with his decision.

"I'm going back out again," said Potter after a moment.

Granger and Weasley exchanged glances. "We know," he said. Draco didn't want to appear too intrigued by the direction of the conversation, so he held up the Spam for closer inspection.

"I want to find - " Potter blinked, re-evaluating their words, and finished, "Wait, no protests?"

"Honestly, Harry." Granger lifted her shoulders, an almost shrug. "You're set on it regardless of the dangers."

Weasley added, "This time we're coming with you, mate."

"If you put it any closer," Granger suddenly said to Draco, "it's going to end up in your nose. You don't have to pretend not to listen."

Potter and Weasley turned inquisitive faces to them; under their attention, Draco fought the rising redness in his face. "I wasn't trying to eavesdrop - I merely aimed to be polite, Granger."

Ignoring Draco's veiled insult, Potter said to his friends, "So you're just coming with me, then?"

"If you didn't have a particular destination in mind, I'd like to go to the hospital."

Draco, though neither medic nor doctor, didn't see anything amiss with Granger's health. He asked, "Why a hospital?"

"Hermione's working with experts to find a cure for the zombies," Weasley said, his chest puffed up and his lips in a broad, proud grin. She gave him a small, private smile; Draco rolled his eyes.

"I didn't really have a plan." Potter's eyes were shining with something like warmth and affection. "But I'm thrilled that you'll join me in scouting."

"What about Malfoy?" asked Weasley with throaty reluctance, as if considering Draco made him nauseated. "What'll he do?"

Draco sniped, "I can take care of myself."

But already apprehension crept into his mind. Draco hated himself as he suddenly realised how dependent he felt upon Potter. What was he going to do, if Potter left? He didn't really know any of the other witches and wizards here, nor the Muggles besides Chickering. Draco considered finding a way to Wiltshire, maybe the Manor -

"You can come," Potter interrupted his thoughts. "I wouldn't stop you, if you wanted to."

Paying no notice to Weasley and Granger's astonishment, their eyes met again. Potter seemed genuine, neither against Draco's involvement nor pushing for it. His words didn't sound forced, like if he had said it only out of politeness.

Hesitantly Granger murmured, "I think Crabbe might be there."

He considered his choices. Draco could either strike out on his own and more than likely die; stay in the museum until he went mad and strike out on his own (with the same result); or enter into a temporary alliance with annoying, but knowledgeable, Gryffindors, and possibly find more answers. I have more options, Draco reassured himself when he decided, I just can't think of them. "I'm in."

Potter announced their departure to the rest of the force. Several of the crew were outwardly dismayed, but very supportive. Draco checked again the bag slung over his hip while Potter, Granger and Weasley said their goodbyes. In his kit he had flares, a torch, two knives (large and small), and extra ammunition. While at the armoury he had traded in the Muggle handgun for something more useful: an assault rifle, Potter called it. He had promised to teach Draco how to use it, and Draco pondered if Potter had actually meant 'field training'.

"We're ready," Granger said to Draco.

They went to the open window that overlooked London Wall, one of the few unbarricaded openings to the museum. Weasley secured the grappling hook and went down first. Draco's acquired gloves were used, but protected his hands (and the developing blisters) from rope burn; and with the harness Potter had impressed upon him, abseiling wasn't difficult.

Potter led the quiet group through the city. If memory served him right, they were nearing where Draco had first encountered Potter. He wanted to further investigate the inn near King Street, to find clues to why he had been there. But asking to stop now would be unsafe, and Draco was certain they weren't supposed to speak.

Between abandoned buildings Draco began to see patches of the Thames when they heard gunshots and shouting. Quickly Potter motioned them to a hotel lobby; they scouted and made sure they were alone among the shattered decorations and peeling wallpaper before Granger unfolded her map.

"We're here," she said, pointing to a section. From what Draco saw, they would have to cross the river to get to the hospital, marked with a red-inked cross.

"We should help," reminded Potter. He and Weasley stood guard on either side of the double doors, watching from the shattered and boarded floor-length windows.

Granger and Weasley nodded their agreement. Draco hesitated but asked anyway, "What if they're... unfriendly?"

"If they're wizard-hating Muggles?" Weasley wrinkled his nose as he spoke.

"We should still help them." Potter had stuck out his lower jaw slightly. "Everybody deserves a chance."

Draco had his reservations but seeing Potter's stubbornness made him bite his tongue. Granger returned the map to her rucksack, but she had furrowed her brows in concern - or, Draco deduced, was it doubt?

Potter and Weasley took front positions and discussed strategy in low voices as they followed the sounds of fighting. Draco stayed alongside Granger, rifle ready in his hands.

"You don't look convinced," said Draco in an undertone to Granger. She was clearly startled by his insight but didn't insult him with asking how he knew.

"Remus Lupin, " she murmured as she removed the safeties on her handguns, "was killed by Muggles when he tried to help them."

He and Draco deposited the beds in front of the door and jammed them together. The weight of the beds would hopefully prevent the zombies breaking through the door.

"Hermione has about thirty bullets, Draco thirty, I have forty shells, and Ron has twenty each weapon."

Panicked screams and shouts from outside the room made Harry catch his breath. Following the voices were gunshots; the rapid fire of machine guns, the slower pulses of small arms, explosions all pervaded the infirmary.

Please, Harry prayed, keep shooting.

Draco and Ron finished setting in place the fifth bed as gradually the tat-tat-tat of the large guns diminished, and only the short punches of handguns and semi-automatics resounded. Harry exchanged fretful glances with Hermione, as Draco and Ron, urged by the destabilising situation, struggled to barricade the door.

"HELP!" The scream and loud thump on the door made Draco lose his grip on the cot he was carrying, and it crashed down when Ron reflexively released his hold. "Let me in PLEASE!"

Ron and Draco shoved at the barricade that they had piled against the door. Sweat beaded on their twisted faces as the jumble of bed frames and padding inched along.

But the desperate pounding on the door ended as abruptly as it began. Hermione struggled to sit up, her eyes tormented from not just physical pain. Harry placed his hands on her lower back and helped her upright. It was silent in the station, save for the screech of the bed frames.

Eventually Ron was able to unbolt the door and cracked it open. He surveyed the situation, then turned to Hermione and Harry with a bleak expression. The corridor was empty.

"The vaccines are here," spoke Draco, looking over Ron's shoulder.

"If you can," Hermione said with a hitch in her voice, "bring them in."

Harry wanted to shout, Don't! as Draco stretched out his arm into the unknown of the corridor. But he recovered the large cool-box without incident, and helped Ron to move the pile back in place.

"You're bleeding." The crimson spots on her bandage shocked Harry. He had brought the cool-box to her cot, and set them down beside her.

"You have to get these to another base." Hermione tapped the lid of the cool-box, then pursed her lips together as she righted her posture.

Ron barked, "We're not gonna leave you!" Leaving Draco and their exertions, he took Hermione's hand.

"I'm as good as dead." She squeezed his broad palm in her smaller fingers and held his fierce gaze. "As soon as the attack lifts, it is imperative that the vaccine is distributed for further efforts."

Harry leaned against the cot and pleaded, "I understand, but - "

"NO!" His eyes were bright. "Hermione, no matter what Harry decides for himself, I am not leaving you."

"Hey," snapped Harry. Just because Ron was keen on her didn't make Harry's affections for Hermione any less relevant. "I'm not saying that Hermione should be left behind, and we've put out our necks a whole hell of a lot for this shit, but she knows what she's talking about better than any of us."

Hermione pulled her hand from Ron's grip and called out, "Draco."

He ambled over from where he had been leaning against the wall. Draco eyed their huddle and wavered at the foot of her cot. "Did you need another reasonable mind to talk sense into Ron?"

Over Ron's anguished shout Hermione asked, "In my position, what would you do?"

"If I were mortally wounded..." Draco crossed his legs and leaned forward on the foot railing, his brows knitted in contemplation. "Staying here, I would most certainly die."

Ron gave Harry a contemptuous, meaningful look. Harry wished Ron wasn't taking this personally.

Draco, though he noticed Ron's expression, dismissed it and continued, "If I tried to leave, I could perish as well." He paused eloquently. "But I would do all I can to fight for survival."

"As I thought."

Harry felt his skin prickle and tingle. Suddenly the blood spots on Hermione's bandages vanished, and she removed a syringe from her pocket, popped the cap from it and injected herself.

"No," cried Ron, falling to his knees.

Hermione removed the syringe and after securing the hypodermic needle she held it out for inspection. With limp fingers Harry took it. The last drop in the vial was pale blue, he saw.

"That was my serum," announced Hermione proudly.

Draco stepped up and roughly pulled Ron from his defeated kneeling position. "Let's go."

Harry adjusted his glasses. The drop was blue, not amber. "I don't understand - "

"She cast a blood-staunching spell," explained Draco as he stuffed ammo into his rucksack. "Then she took the magic-dampening potion."

Harry must've still appeared bewildered because Draco, seeing his expression, whipped out a hand and shook his good arm. "Harry, she's on borrowed time now."

The immediate awareness that Hermione had with her decision bought them some time spurred them into activity. Efficiently they divvied up their supplies, and for the second time Ron and Draco cleared the entrance. Ron lifted Hermione into his arms again, the vaccines in a bag safely in her hands, and followed Harry and Draco into the corridor.

Harry took rear guard again, and the smears of blood on the walls and floors and absence of bodies disquieted him. Then they approached the office in which he had met Shacklebolt and he saw a slain Muggle man in the doorway. The man lay prone with his feet over the threshold; blood pooled around the gash in his neck.

He was trying to get in, thought Harry as they moved on. I wonder if he was whom we heard.

They found other bodies, all Muggles though, in the dormitory and other spaces as they crept to the main entrance. All of them had fatal injuries, but nothing indicative of post-mortem savaging or attacks. The doors to the main entrance were shut but not barred. Harry advanced to stand beside Draco. On a silent count, they nudged the doors open.

Draco whispered, "Merlin."

The other bodies, the remaining personnel of the fire station, were immobile, colourful islands on the steps and pavement outside the front door. Vashisht, the wizard who'd found them, the physician - they were all there. Harry's heart fell when he saw on the bottom step the green-robed figure of Gwen, crouched unnaturally still.

A terrified shout drew their attention to around the corner. Yards from the intersection a lone black man stood surrounded by a crowd. He threw a spell at the mob, but the tide surged in other directions, reaching with red-splotched hands at his tall frame.

"Kingsley!" screamed Harry. He ran forward and fired twice at the zombies that cornered him

The whites showed around Shacklebolt's dark eyes as he swivelled around and shouted, "No, run!"

Harry couldn't shake off Draco's hand on his arm, but he was rooted to the spot as he saw Shacklebolt's hand dart out of the crowd. Light reflected off the vibrant gold tube in his palm. Then Shacklebolt injected himself with the vaccine, and the horde overwhelmed him.

He was surrounded, and he gave in, just like he said he would, Harry thought numbly. Of course he would let his guard defend him as long as possible, and he was almost near the road - only steps and he would've broken free! - and -

"Harry!"

He snapped out of his stupor to find Draco's face in his own. His grey eyes were bloodshot and wide, and the crease between his eyebrows was his mark of concern - for Harry. Draco, Hermione and Ron were still alive, and they needed to stay alive. There was a resistance to uphold, and Harry saw in his friends' faces the determination to make it.

But, it dawned on him, firing at the horde was a bad idea. They ran away from the crowd of zombies that had suddenly become interested in them. They were heading towards the Thames, Harry reckoned. He remembered another safehouse in these parts, and he hoped it was on the river.

"How're you?" shouted Harry as they navigated the streets.

"Never better." Carrying Hermione, Ron was slower than his usual pace, and his face was lined with effort.

Abruptly Draco back-pedalled with a shout of "Shit!" and fired his rifle. From a bookstore four zombies leapt out and charged at them. Draco rolled out of the way of a lunging undead, and Harry recognised Crabbe.

"Oh fuck me," Ron shouted.

Another group of zombies had spilled out from a desolate building they had just passed, and were circling Ron. Harry fired at the three undeads a split second before he recognised them, too. But Crabbe, Goyle, Seamus and Dean, and the other zombies that Harry and Draco shot at were on their feet again before Harry could reload.

Hermione screamed, "Just run!"

They dashed down an alley, Draco far in the lead. Cans of years-old trash spilled their contents on the slick stone. Ron slipped on an empty bag of crisps, nearly going to his knees.

"Go around me, will you?!" he hollered at Harry.

Harry darted around Ron and Hermione to navigate a path for them. A glance over his shoulder found Hermione firing over Ron's shoulder at the undeads pursuing them.

"Draco!" Harry shouted up the alley at the receding figure. "Don't get separated from us!"

They emerged from the alley onto the main road, and Harry ran past Draco. He was still running but had slowed until he was abreast of Ron and Hermione.

"Sorry mate," Draco said to them. "Anything I can do?"

"Yeah," wheezed Ron. Harry glanced over his shoulder; Ron's stony visage had cracked into a toothy grin, despite his fatigue. "I've an itch right over my - "

His eyes rolled up and his mouth opened in a soundless shout when the bullet bit between his shoulder blades. Draco skidded, trying to stop abruptly, and fell on his back. Ron fell forward and Hermione's scream pierced Harry's ears.

No, his mind repeated as he backtracked.

"Oh God."

Draco pulled Ron's body off of Hermione and tenderly laid him on his back. Hermione pushed herself to a sitting position with sheer will as red dyed her dressing.

"Ron."

Harry didn't feel his knees clack against the pavement. He touched Ron's neck, his nose, his arm. His chest shallowly, slowly fell and rose with breath, but Ron stared with furrowed, blue eyes intense and concentrated on the sky above him.

"Go, Harry."

"No." Harry leaned over his best friend's body. "No, I can't."

"Draco, take Harry and go."

Harry felt himself pulled away from Ron and he didn't resist. Because Ron didn't protest, he didn't move, he didn't even meet Harry's imploring gaze. Then Draco gently guided Harry to Hermione, who was still breathing, who was rummaging in Ron's rucksack, who was beseeching him with her wet eyes. He would never see her again, nor Ron, it registered with him.

"Love you," whispered Harry into her hair as he hugged her.

She murmured shakily, "Take care of yourself, Harry."

Harry touched Ron's brow. He waited as Draco awkwardly embraced Hermione, released a self-effacing laugh at her private words and stood.

They ran faster than Harry had thought possible. Seconds later, the thunderous explosion shook the pavement under their feet. After that, Harry heard only the slap of their trainers meeting the ground and their laboured breathing.
