Draco hunched with Harry under the altar dais at the rear of the chapel. They had found the stone pillared-building in minutes. They hadn't any choice but to take shelter; they were exhausted from grief and running, and the chapel was there and miraculously vacant of zombies. They had loaded all the pews against the doors, and when they had found the trap door into the platform it had seemed reasonable to crawl under and wait.

It was dark, and the soft noises from beside Draco alarmed him at first. He reached out and his hand bumped against Harry.

"They're dead," spoke the raspy voice.

He was stifling his sobs in his arms, but Draco heard them regardless. Draco held the shuddering body close, and rested his clammy forehead against Harry's warm shoulder. The physical exertion was making his head hurt again.

I wish I could do more for you, thought Draco wistfully.

Hermione and Ron weren't his friends, really, though he had grown fond of them. He just didn't know enough about them to comfort Harry. So he did what he could. They crouched like that, legs asleep and backs curved uncomfortably against the board and stone above them, until Harry's sobs eased.

"I've got the wireless," Harry said. His voice was thick with mucus, but steady.

"Can you get a hold of anyone?"

Draco waited as Harry searched for the handheld. Then he said into the radio, "Is anyone out there in London?"

For minutes they waited, the hope bitter and tangible in Draco's mouth. If - such a tentative if! - there were other living humans out there, they would surely be aware of the zombie uprising and wouldn't risk their lives for two unknowns. Even facing that reality, Draco still hoped the radio would crackle to life, would bring them a chance at survival. But there was no response from the other end, and with his arm still slung over Harry's shoulder's Draco felt more than heard him sigh.

"We should explore a bit..."

Draco thought Harry was talking about something else and was about to scold Harry. But the notion was overruled when he imagined scorch marks and flesh burned onto pavement. "Yes."

They stretched out the cramps in their legs before removing the hasty barricade on the chapel door. (Nothing like making a hobble for escape, Draco had mused as sensation returned to his calves.) Back on the roadway they retraced their steps to the intersection where they had separated from Ron and Hermione. The closer they went, the more extensive the surface damage was until they came to a desolate, blackened area.

"Look." Harry outlined with his finger the blast zone. "They detonated five, maybe seven of their grenades. They - the bodies must've burned from the blast."

Draco went to the centre of the zone. He ignored Harry's gasp and rubbed his finger on the paving.

"Odd," he announced, "there's no residue."

Harry joined him. "You mean - could the zombies have moved Her - the bodies?" His face contorted from fury. "Those mindless fuckers, I can't believe it!"

"No - hey!"

Draco pointed to the ransacked building, in which he had spied movement. As he had predicted, a figure emerged from the shadowed interior but didn't come out to the street.

"It's one of them."

The hatred in Harry's voice unsettled him. Then Harry impulsively fired his gun at the building. Draco scrambled to his feet and backed behind Harry.

"Are you trying to get us killed?" hissed Draco.

But then the figure materialised as a familiar pink-haired woman, who gracefully stepped over the ruins of the window frame and stood, waiting, on the kerb.

"Tonks!" Wonder, faith, anxiety and frustration all roiled in Draco's heart. And then he took in her pale grey visage and the old, unhealed injuries on her person.

"Merlin," gasped Harry, "she's a zombie."

They turned and ran, back toward the chapel. Tonks was an undead - how could that be? Draco remembered how everyone had said that she had escaped with her aunt, Draco's mother and Severus to France when Britain was quarantined. But obviously she hadn't stayed in the continent.

"Do you remember," Harry said between breaths, "anything at all? Any clue as to why Tonks is here?"

"Nothing," replied Draco as the dread rose with bile in his throat. "What's the plan?"

"Ha!" Harry spat out the sound like a stone. "Fuck if I know."

They ran past the chapel without pausing. Then Harry said, "Up ahead! A tube station, let's go."

With their torches out they leapt down the stairs sinking underground, their beams of light bouncing off the steps. It was nearly full darkness beyond the dim circle of light from the stairwell. Draco arced his torch and saw the light reflected off regularly-spaced panes of glass. Starved of electricity, the trains hibernated at the platform and waited until its passengers returned. Harry approached a car and pried open the door.

"C'mon," he whispered.

Harry shined his torch over the inside of the carriage. They were alone, Draco saw as he slid the door closed. At Harry's signal they dropped to the floor and switched off their torches. Silence fell over them as they waited for their night vision to come in.

"What have you got left?" murmured Harry.

Draco thumbed through the contents of his rucksack. "Vaccine, serum, ten bullets, two knives, flares, torch, map."

"Same, sans map plus wireless."

Draco heard Harry fumbling in his pouch. He quickly found what he had been looking for, and spoke, "Repeat, is anyone alive in London?"

"I don't know if you'll get reception down here."

"True."

They stood by for a response. Draco tapped his knee restlessly. He dimly saw Harry rub the pads of his thumb over the handheld's speaker.

This waiting will kill us, Draco thought wildly, before the zombies find us first. Well, why not?

On impulse Draco bent forward to kiss Harry - hell, if they were going to die, at least he'd enjoy one last snog. Only he miscalculated and ended up with a mouthful of Harry's nose.

"Ugh," laughed Harry, breath warm on Draco's chin. "Ever heard of dental hygiene?"

Draco found his lips in the dark. Harry met him, pushing forward onto his knees, pulling them together with his hands. They aspired over each other's mouths and inhaled separately, taking in each other's spent air. He tried and he was sure Harry put in as much effort, but the kiss felt forced and tepid, nothing like their earlier embraces.

The radio fizzled to life, and amidst the crackling he could make out a woman's voice.

"Crossing point... survivors..." said the speaker, tinny over the radio, "ship... Thames... coast of..."

Reception faded away and they released each other. Draco breathed in the last taste of him on his lips, almost smothered by the palpable reluctance and disappointment in the stuffy air.

"Guess that's the siren call," Harry finally said.

The window shattered behind Harry and light blazed into Draco's face. He fell backwards, screwing his eyes shut and squelching the sudden dampness in them.

"Dra - "

Harry's shout drowned in a gurgle. Draco forced his stinging eyes open.

The blonde zombie that had torn apart Sheldon in the university stood behind Harry, her hands woven around Harry's throat as she lifted him from his knees. His eyes bulged unseeing to the roof of the train car. His lenses crunched to slivers with the glass shards under the feet of other zombies that crawled into the carriage.

"HARRY!"

Draco fired at the zombies that flowed behind Harry, pushing to rush past and attack, but his bullets were ineffective. Why weren't they dying?! The zombies jolted from the force, but dismissed his shots like they were flies. He senselessly screamed, and slowly, Harry's eyes met his own.

Harry mouthed, "Go."

He released one final barrage of bullets until the cartridge clicked hollowly, carving out a path through the zombies outside the car. Draco broke the window as he vaulted over seats and hit the platform running. He turned when he reached the stairs.

A regally garbed zombie witch approached Harry, and the blonde hair of his warden turned shocking pink. The other zombie flicked her wrist, and Nymphadora Tonks released Harry's neck and he fell bonelessly out of sight. The witch tilted her head, and Draco recognised his aunt Andromeda Tonks.

Oh my god, she's one of them!

He pounded up the stairs, miraculously without pursuit, and launched onto the street. Then, as if his presence set off a tripwire, they extricated themselves from the interiors and shadows of every building around him. Grey skin unified them, but besides that they seemed to come from all walks of death. Draco spun; every turn brought more zombies surfacing. He glimpsed the flat expanse of water down the street, and knife in each hand he pelted to the river.

Draco slashed at zombies that stepped into his way, stabbed those that accosted him, and pushed through the growing, surging horde. The assault felt like it wouldn't end. But though he avoided serious injury as he inched his way to the water, the fight took its toll on Draco. He found himself missing more and more, and cutting fruitlessly through the air. His strength lagged and he was jostled by the red-flecked arms of the stronger zombies when he tried to push back.

Through a gap he spotted the salvation of the pier. With a spurt of adrenaline Draco kicked the zombie blocking his way in the stomach and jumped over its flailing body. Desperation and fatigue had chipped away his co-ordination, and he landed awkwardly, angry pain shooting through his ankle. But he was free! Tuning out the rumble of the rabble behind him, Draco ran for all his might to the pier and didn't stop until he reached the end of the planks.

Where is the ship?! He scanned the water, but he saw only decrepit commercial vessels and leisure boats that listlessly bobbed at the surface. Abandoned.

"Draco."

No.... He turned with trepidation, unwilling to believe it. But he couldn't deny the truth before his eyes: Narcissa Malfoy was at the forefront of the zombie crowd that had severed him from land.

"Mother."

Narcissa outstretched her arms, inviting Draco for an embrace. Dark blue robes modestly covered her slender body, but did not hide the pallor of her hands and face. Draco pointed the knife at her (when had he lost his other knife?), unable to conceal the tremor in his hand as he edged toward the end of the pier.

I'd rather die than be mauled by them, he made up his mind.

"You can speak?"

"My son," she said with clear regret. "I know that you are extremely upset and confused - "

"How long?" shouted Draco. "How long have you been like that?"

Narcissa let her hands fall back to her side. "A year ago, I willingly underwent the transformation."

"You... you chose to become a zombie."

"I did." As she spoke, Andromeda and Nymphadora Tonks materialised at her side from the mob behind. "Your aunt and cousin Transformed, as well."

Draco heard the emphasis that time.

"In France we were able to isolate the component in the bodies of witches and wizards that made them into 'zombies'." Narcissa sighed, the only sign of her disapproval of the term. "We found a critical difference in our blood from that of our fellow magic users. The blood that is in my sister's blood, her daughter's blood, my blood - and yours - that blood was the key.

"We Transformed, yes, but not to the mindless herd members that used to run rampant all over Britain." Narcissa smiled at him. "We are a better, elevated lineage now."

"Of course we had to amplify that factor," interjected Tonks with her brilliant grin. Draco stared at the crimson gashes on her face that did not bleed. "And then we duplicated it, to distribute to other wizards and witches."

"Without my skills," intoned a deep voice that stirred familiarity, relief and dread, "we wouldn't have succeeded."

Severus Snape stalked forward and halted at Narcissa's side. He removed his hand from his robe sleeve, and Draco saw the glint of amber behind glass in his sallow hands.

"Why?" Draco implored. "You're telling me that, that you've become undead but you're not, and you want others to become - to Transform too!" He motioned at the cityscape behind them. "Stop me if you fucking know this, but you're killing everyone!"

"No."

Hermione separated from the crowd and stepped around Tonks. She had removed the bandages from her midriff, and Draco saw shredded grey skin around the ghastly wound that did not bleed.

"Draco," her tone loaded with meaning, "the vaccines are completely the opposite."

"They saved our lives," added Ron as he joined Hermione at the front, hale and hearty for all that a bullet in the back had nearly done him in.

"We had wanted to return and quietly help our community Transform," Andromeda continued the narration. "Your mother wanted you to wake up in a safer situation."

Tonks picked up, "Instead we had to track you down. Thanks tons, cousin." She winked at him. "You helped bring us to other safehouses in the city."

"Are you fucking kidding me?!" Draco violently waved his knife; he wanted to stab them like he had stabbed and slashed the zombies only minutes ago, but he couldn't ignore the growing sense that they weren't zombies. "You and your lot attacked the bases?"

"We saved those witches and wizards." Narcissa spoke calmly, "You heard Bruce Sheldon's plan, didn't you? If we hadn't switched our vaccines for his poisons, he would have murdered hundreds before anyone could stop him."

Grasping at straws, Draco shouted, "What about the Muggles? The other wizards and witches? They're still dead!"

Then, what he had most feared since seeing Hermione and Ron was fulfilled. Harry, with purple bruises on his grey neck, stepped forward to say, "I know."

"No," said Draco with a hitch in his voice. "Not you too, Harry."

"I feel the same as you, Draco." Harry spoke with unforced sorrow, "I wish that the Muggles didn't have to die, but you understand as well as I do that they blamed us."

"It is our fault!" In frustration, Draco bit his lip and tasted blood. "We turn into murderous, savage beasts and kill Muggles and magic-users alike!"

"Is it our fault that we have magic?" Severus removed his wand. "No, Draco, and we shouldn't blame ourselves for having the talent. Muggles have ruthlessly persecuted other Muggles for innate traits like race and gender. However, unlike the Muggles that have targeted our kind, we have transcended that horrible aspect of Transformation."

"And get this," Ron said blithely as he took out his own wand, "we can use magic again, and even better than before!"

With a flick of his wand, he repaired the hole in Hermione's stomach. At her upturned grateful look to Ron, Draco wanted to vomit. She was dead, for Merlin's sake! He tried to swallow but his tongue protested, and his resulting coughs scarred his throat.

Narcissa said, "The Transformation will occur for those that have already fallen - yes, Draco, the vaccines can accomplish that, too. As for the Muggles, we will deal with them when witches and wizards are reunited as a people."

Draco blinked to clear his vision, but that did nothing to stem the increasing blurriness in his eyes. What was happening to him?

"Harry," he implored, "please, listen to me. This is ridiculous! I don't want to be a part of, of what they're saying. Harry."

Incautiously he put away his knife and took Harry's hand. If nobody else would listen to him, if they were all swayed by this monstrous insanity, he had to get through to Harry.

"Harry, Harry, please, you're alive, right? Let's leave, like we're supposed to! We have to get away from this - "

Draco shifted his gaze to the zombies but found that his eyes couldn't focus on them. Their figures blurred and swayed.

"I - I like you very much, Harry, I've grown to like you so much, so please stop kidding around because you're tearing my heart from my chest."

His muscles surrendered to atrophy, and with nothing keeping him together, he fell to his knees and his hands slipped from Harry's. What's wrong with me? he asked himself as his vision plunged in and out of darkness.

"The stasis spell is wearing off," said Severus, as if at the other end of a tunnel though Draco knew he was only feet away.

Narcissa added in a gentle tone, "The Transformation is not yet complete for him."

Draco knew he should be horrified, but it was so hard to think through the tendrils of fog that squeezed his mind into incoherency. His head pounded, but he knew he wasn't bleeding through his bandage.

"It's okay, Draco," said Harry very near him.

He was kneeling beside Draco and had an arm around his shoulders, like how Draco had held him in the chapel. Only he was pulling something out of Draco's rucksack - a vial of amber liquid.

With such love, such an amazing and startling amount of affection, Harry murmured, "You've been with me, with us, since the beginning, and I won't throw you away."

A wet breeze carrying the scent of the sea tickled his nose. Draco stirred from his nap and lazily blinked once, twice. He'd fallen asleep on the veranda again - terrible habit, that was. But the temperature was just right, his reclining chair was sinfully comfortable, and the late afternoon sun warmed his sandalled feet. Draco could never resist that combination.

"You're awake."

Draco glanced to the side. Past the teal-painted stone walls, a black tousled head poked out of the open screened door. His eyes met Draco's, and with a grin he came over and noisily kissed Draco.

"You won't get to do this for much longer," Harry joked when they parted. "The rain will chase you in as soon as you try to sleep."

"Good." Draco stretched and yawned. Eyeing Harry's tall socks and Bermuda shorts he said, "Then maybe you'll stop making us go to the south shore, you damn tourist. This morning tired me out, that's all."

He nodded smugly. "Sure."

Harry crouched at Draco's side and their hands naturally came together. Their palms fit like poetry, his thin fingers woven between Harry's slightly larger fingers, their skin tinted slightly different and the only hint of a seam between their hands.

Feeling incredibly sentimental all of a sudden, Draco looked away, past their veranda steps at the rocky hillside that tumbled to the sea. His great-aunt's home was better than the manor, in many aspects. If they came out at sunset, Draco knew, they would have a magnificent view of the reaching dusk over the ocean; now, he saw a thin line of darker blue where the sky met the sea. The house was situated perfectly on the hill with views to die for, but most importantly, there was only so much of their history in there as they wanted to put into it.

"It's Harbour Night," said Harry softly, as if hesitant to alter the mood.

"I know."

"We promised to meet Hermione and Ron in town."

"Yeah." Draco yawned again.

He stood and pulled Harry to his feet. Regardless of how much they had left behind, Harry was one part of his history that Draco wanted to keep. Struck with the whim, Draco twirled Harry to him and captured his mouth with his lips.

"Love you," murmured Draco when they parted.

Harry appreciatively smiled, a blush on his cheeks. "You too."

They renewed their glamours and Apparated from their hilltop house.

Draco suddenly had an idea of what Harry was about to say and, grasping for an excuse to delay the inevitable, interrupted, "No, Harry, now's not the time--" "Hold it, Potter," broke in a familiarly thick voice. Draco slowly turned, dread bubbling in his stomach. Vincent Crabbe and Gregory Goyle stood shoulder-to-shoulder blocking the entrance to the bathroom, wands pointed right at them. "Crabbe. Goyle." Draco's eyes narrowed; they had their usual simpleton expressions, but he knew that they were surprisingly stubborn. "How come you aren't with Voldemort?" asked Harry. "We was hiding in the corridor," replied Gregory with a nod. "We can do Diss-lusion Charms now! And then, you turned up right in front of us and said you were looking for a secret. "It's Potter the Dark Lord wants." "But wouldn't you want to know what the secret is?" cajoled Draco, his tone sickening to his ears. Funny how I haven't talked to them in over a year, yet they're still as simple as they were before. "Wouldn't it be nice to tell You-Know-Who the secret of Harry Potter?" He could always count on Gregory; his face lit up like fireworks on a night sky. "Yeah, what is it?" "Greg--" Vincent moved a meaty arm to try and stop his friend, but Harry's wand slid into his palm and caught his eye. "No, Potter! CRUCIO!" Harry ducked to the ground, and the curse splintered the giant mirror; Draco hastily threw a protective spell at Harry, shielding him from the worst of the shrapnel. Then he dodged Vincent's next hex, and it shattered the stone wall behind where Draco's head was. "No, Vince!" shouted Gregory. "It's only Potter we're after--" "He don't care if we kill somebody else," retorted Vincent with a snarl, "What's the diff--" "Expelliarmus!" Harry disarmed Goyle, whose wand landed in a cubicle, splashing on the flooded floor. He yelped and dove for cover, but Vincent wheeled around, swinging his wand. "Avada Kedavra!" screamed Vincent; Harry jumped and avoided the green beam of light, and it shattered the sinks on either side of the pipe. Vincent flung another curse at him and taunted, "What's that you got behind you, Potter?" "Impedimenta!" Vincent moved surprisingly fast and Draco's spell only caught him on his calf. He went down to one knee, yelling another Killing Curse at Draco. As Draco threw himself out of the way, Harry rolled and shouted, "Stupefy!" Vincent went down like dead weight, landing face-first on the floor. After conjuring rope that magically bound him, Draco took pity on Crabbe and nudged him over with his foot, so that he wouldn't drown in three inches of water. "Accio Goyle's Wand!" With his wand in Draco's hand, Gregory whimpered from the cubicle, "What're you gonna do to me? Don't hurt me!" "Come out here, Goyle!" shouted Draco, tightly gripping his former friend's wand. Gregory might have heard a note of familiarity in Draco's voice, but it was more likely fear that made him obey. He crawled out from the cubicle, his head ducked. The sight of Vincent's bound body made him squeak. "While I appreciate that you tried to stop Crabbe from killing us," Draco spoke, fury still strong in him, "we can't let you leave and snitch to Voldemort where we are." Gregory's shoulders shook as he heaved and sniffled. Calmly, Draco held his wand out and cast a nonverbal Stunning Spell. He pushed Gregory's unconscious form to lie beside Vincent's and threw another binding spell on them. Harry was on his feet wiping the blood from his cuts when Draco finished. "I never knew Crabbe was so--so vicious," murmured Harry when Draco was in earshot. Regarding them impassively, Draco answered, "Must've learned it from the Carrows." "David, I--" "Harry!" shouted Ron as he whizzed out of the pipe on the broomstick. Hermione was perched in front of him, carefully clutching a parcel wrapped with his outer robe, and shrieked when they stopped just before the opposite wall. "Why didn't you fol--" "What are Crabbe and Goyle doing here?" Hermione cut in, her lips pale as she got down from the broomstick. "They ambushed us," Harry replied. He took the parcel from her and removed from it a large, yellowed curved fang. "How many of 'em did you get?" "We had to try a few before one worked." Hermione withdrew the cup from her bag, now tarnished and blackened as if she had dropped it into a fire. "So we took as many as we could, in hope that one will work for you." Draco brought out the diadem and tossed it into the last intact sink on the wall. Harry placed in his palm one of the fangs, cautious not to let the venomous end touch his skin. "I think I'll take a stab at it, shall I?" said Draco with a mocking laugh. Ron guffawed, Hermione rolled her eyes with a sigh and a twitch of her lips, and Harry grinned. Draco went through three fangs before, finally, he pierced the diadem with the fourth fang. A bloodlike, tarry substance beaded around the wound, and then it violently vibrated in the sink. A shriek of pain resonated from it, and then as quickly as the inhuman reaction began, it ended. The diadem's surface turned rusty black and cracked; it looked like someone had laid a delicate, lacy spider web on the diadem, with the center over the wound. "Now only the snake is left," Harry said into the quiet that followed the keening scream. Draco gathered the diadem and basilisk fang and put them, carefully, in his robe pocket. Ron hefted the sling, saying, "And we have plenty--" Loud yells and the ringing of deflected hexes interrupted him. The castle shook more violently this time than the last times, and they were thrown off balance. More candles fell off their holders, their flames extinguished when they hit water, and mortar from the ceiling and walls clouded the surface. "Harry," Hermione said hastily as she shoved the bundle of fangs into her bag, "You need to locate Voldemort, he'll have the snake. Look inside his head--do it!" Draco bit the inside of his cheek; Harry had that vulnerable expression again, but he didn't object. Harry closed his eyes and, after a moment, he jerked his head back. Screams echoed from the rest of the castle in the old bathroom. Draco wondered where Moaning Myrtle was. She'd been kind to him in his sixth year, listening to him when none of his Slytherin friends had, consoling him when his failures had added up. She's a ghost, he told himself. It's not like she can die again. But he didn't deny the hope that she was all right. With a gasp, Harry came back to himself. He exhaled sharply and said, "He's in the Shrieking Shack. The snake's with him, it's got some sort of magical protection around it. He's just sent Lucius Malfoy to find Snape." Draco wanted to sick up. Oh god, he thought, breathing shallowly, oh god, oh god, Severus, Father-- "David!" Hermione firmly tugged his arm. "We have to go!" "My parents--" His whisper wasn't heard as they ran out of the bathroom, Hermione pulling Draco, leaving Gregory and Vincent bound on the ground.

Thanks to and U for beta-ing. *** This Changes Everything *** On an early November evening in the outskirts of London, a gust of wind stirred the faded curtains in a tiny flat's grime-etched windows. One of the residents of the flat, three hours prior, had left them open for ventilation before scrunching into an exhausted, rumpled heap on the sofa. Unfolded on the scratched coffee table was a copy of the newspaper, open to the meteorologist's confident report of a 20% chance of showers (with partly sunny skies, high of 11', excellent day for a lark). A rising breeze ruffled the pages, along with old napkins on the table, a discolored paper sack on the cluttered floor, and the resident's dark hair. A solitary charred hunk of commercial fire log dwelled in the flat's small fireplace, but its inflammability didn't hinder a flame from bursting to life. The fire was small, but robust, and fed on the breeze coming through the windows. It also bore a passing resemblance to a human face. "Al!" The sleeping tenant burrowed his head further into the threadbare cushions of the sofa. The face, now more clearly defined with feminine features, hissed again, "Albus!" He flopped over to face the fire, though his eyes were still closed, and mumbled, "Wuzzit?" "Incoming!" Finally opening his eyes to blink blearily at the face, Albus Potter said, "Huh?" As quickly as it flared, the fire vanished. Albus was still processing the abrupt departure of his cousin's face when the door buzzed. "One mo'," muttered Albus as he pushed himself to his feet. As the buzzing pitched, he banged his shins against the coffee table, and then crossed the few treacherous meters of discarded take-out boxes, old socks, outdated magazines, and a Quidditch jersey, to the door. Bzzz! the large door bee hummed, flying erratically before him. It actually flew in the figure of a 'W', but patterns were beyond Albus when he was still drowsy. "All right, I'm getting it," hissed Albus as he swatted at the insect to undo the deadbolt. Then he grabbed the knob with one hand, hit the door above the lock with his other hand, and wrenched open the door from the tight frame. "Hello." "Hi," said Scorpius Malfoy as he took off his carmine and chartreuse sombrero. "Can I step in for a bit?" "Um. Er. Yes." Albus hastily pushed himself upright from leaning against the frame, and stepped back to let in the other man. "Take your, er, coat?" Scorpius thrust the sombrero at Albus and stepped into the flat. Under a neon green cape, Scorpius wore a crimson short jacket with lime green edging, matching skin-tight trousers, and coral-pink stockings. His brass heeled shoes were muted once he stepped onto the carefully-cultivated debris, but his march down the hall to one of the two bedrooms was no less forceful. "How are you doing?" asked Scorpius as he kicked open the door without ruffling his metallic cape. Inside the room, thrown over the dresser, bed and floor was a mess of Quidditch gear, old brooms, and letters; with purpose Scorpius went straight for the dresser. Albus stood stunned in the doorway as Scorpius yanked open the top drawer and tossed some articles onto the bed. "I'm okay," said Albus faintly. What is going on? he wondered. So far, in a pile distinct from the rest of the mess were two shirts, a pair of pants, and a book. Scorpius paused to punt closed the bottom drawer. "How's that job of yours working out? Aren't you a Hit Wizard or something?" "Obliviator's Assistant, actually. Nine to five. Super. What are you doing?" "I'm getting my things." From the closet, Scorpius threw a jacket over his shoulder in the general direction of the floor. "Oh. Okay." Albus was lightheaded with confusion, sleep deprivation, and proximity to Scorpius. He started nervously kneading the brim of the sombrero. "I don't get it." Hearing Albus's desperate tone, Scorpius paused his scavenging to look back at Albus. "I'll only be a few minutes, Potter," he replied in a gentle voice. "I apologize for intruding on you like this, but I won't bother you again." With a brilliant display of the diversity of the English language, Albus answered hastily, "It's okay. I don't mind." Scorpius stopped compiling his things (Albus figured that much out--that white-and-grey tie was definitely not classy enough for the tenant) and walked around the bed to where Albus was standing. His shoes squelched on the exposed carpet, but otherwise made a crunching noise on the visible mess. He took in Albus's tired and perplexed face, the awkward worrying of his sombrero, and Albus's mismatched socks. "You're upset," stated Scorpius after his analysis. "Yes. Er, no." Albus dropped the vividly-colored sombrero and scrambled to pick it up before the floor consumed it. "I'm just confused. Why are you here again?" Scorpius repeated slowly, "I'm getting my stuff." "Oh." Albus put one and one together. "You and James...?" "Yes." His tone became bitter as he continued, "This time, for good." Scorpius returned to hunting for his belongings amongst his ex-boyfriend's stuff, and Albus went out to the living area and flopped onto the sofa. He stared at the fireplace, then turned his attention to the hat in his hands. Albus curiously sniffed at the hat and inspected it before putting it on. It's still warm, he thought. Albus closed his eyes, leaned back and tilted the sombrero forward. Although the felt lining was a little damp from sweat, and the hat smelled like the floor of a pub, Albus kept it on. Stupid James, doesn't know what he's doing... "I think I'm finished," chirped Scorpius as he left James's bedroom. Albus knocked off the hat and twisted around guiltily as Scorpius re-entered the living area. "If you see anything else of mine, could you let me know?" Albus coughed and replied, "Yeah, sure." He held up the sombrero. "Want your hat back?" Scorpius considered, then nodded. "Just drop it here." Albus tossed the sombrero at Scorpius's coral-stockinged feet. The fascinated tenant watched as Scorpius dropped his armful of belongings onto the hat, then cast a shrinking charm on the overflowing articles. Instantly the clothes, books, and other paraphernalia shrunk to fit inside the hat. "Thanks." Scorpius crouched down and picked up the full sombrero. "I'll leave you alone now. I hope I won't have to bother you again." "It's fine," Albus protested weakly. Not really knowing what to do, he got up and stood before Scorpius. "I didn't mind you stopping by, even if it was for James." Scorpius's smile dazzled his already dumbfounded mind. "Maybe I will see you again." The blond approached the door, but halted at a faint buzzing sound. Tilting his head to listen, Scorpius asked, "Is that yours?" "Oh, um." Albus stepped around Scorpius to swat at the bee buzzing feebly around the knob. He waved the insect toward its bachelor hive above the entryway. "Yes. The door bee. Tells me when there's a wizard or witch outside." Scorpius raised an eyebrow. "Your invention?" At Albus's nod, the costumed man grinned. "I am not surprised. Cheers, Potter." "Bye," mumbled Albus when Scorpius stepped out. He closed and locked the door, and pressed his ear against the discolored wood. Though he listened for the familiar crack of Disapparition, what he heard instead was a menacing rumble of thunder. Rain began to beat upon his window sills, and dashed away all chances of eavesdropping. Suddenly remembering earlier, Albus lurched across the living area to fall down before the fireplace. He grabbed a handful of Floo powder and tossed it onto the hunk of log. Albus yelled, "Rose's flat!" and thrust his face into the fire. "Rose!" he hollered. His eyes adjusted to the wavering perspective of the fire, and he saw his pyjama-ed cousin come into view. "What is it?" "Did you know, Scorpius Malfoy came by?" Through the Floo, Albus couldn't tell Rose was red to the roots of her auburn hair, but he could definitely hear a familiar voice laughing hysterically. At the open windows, Albus intended to secure them against the hard rain. Instead, as rain accumulated around his socked feet, he gazed past the damp curtains and despaired, What am I going to do? *** Albus Potter first realized the extent of his dilemma when his brother had introduced the young Malfoy to their parents. Albus heard the surprised murmurs of students, even faculty, in the stadium. "Indeed it is! But he doesn't seem to have a problem flying." "Yes, but--" "Chaser Weasley brings the Quaffle up mid-pitch, passes it to Kirk, Kirk ducks below Norris's Bludger, throws it at Bones--Bones fumbles, drops the Quaffle! Tonda recovers the Quaffle, returns to Gryffindor side, dodges Beater Weasley, throws to Hopkins. Another goal for Slytherin!" From the other side of the field Albus faintly saw James stopped flying and looked behind at his broom. Then he flew a little and, lo and behold, a few large lazy bubbles formed from the tip. James flew faster and the stream of bubbles became more dense. When he stopped, his broom didn't make more bubbles. And watching it all was Bones, who did not see the Quaffle coming at him. "That confirms it," Lovegood intoned calmly, "James Potter is making bubbles." *** Over the course of the game, James's broom branched out to make gold, silver, red and green bubbles, in various shapes and forms behind him as he doggedly continued to fly. Madam Hooch didn't find the bubbling against the rules, so to her frustration, bubbles continued to fill the air above the pitch. It was too much for the spectators, who became more interested in the bubbles than the game, and for Gryffindor Quidditch team, all of whom fought to regain points. "The bubble butterflyfish looks rather lovely, doesn't it? Slytherin leads, 220-160." "Well Nell, I'm personally a fan of the pink dragon swimming around what looks to be an impression of the Giant Squid." "You're right... the gold bubbles for suckers is a good touch--Zabini flies through the Giant Squid, holding a... sucker?" "It's the Snitch! Zabini caught the Snitch, and right under Macmillan's nose." "And with that, Slytherin wins the match, 370-160." Lovegood's voice was clearly heard over the cheers and polite applause. "I know how easily it is to be distracted, Macmillan, that dragon didn't have a chance against the Squid." As Albus began to descend, James flew over with his stream of bubbles. "How'd you do it?" asked the elder Potter, admiration and amusement in his tone. Albus grinned smugly, popped a bubble floating near and said, "Check your broom twigs." James's mouth fell open. "How did you get at my broom?" "How did you get my boxers?" With the last word, Albus landed on the pitch and rejoined his team. "Great defense, Potter!" complimented Norris, heartily clapping Albus on his back. "Our Chasers made wonderful goals too," said Albus with a nod to the three. Hopkins, Tonda and Warrington lifted Zabini onto their shoulders with a cheer. "Great job!" they cheered. The dark-skinned Seeker grinned proudly at the team. Zabini then saw Albus and waved him over. Leaning over, "Thanks for the heads-up," whispered Zabini when Albus was near. "Of course." Albus was pleased to have recouped whatever respect he lost from his House, but was more glad about his truly spectacular prank. *** The next evening, Albus was still in good spirits, high enough that he went to the scheduled study session without any of his customary irritation at Malfoy. After dinner, book bag in tote, he tapped on the door of the third floor classroom. Rose opened the door and said, "Hey." She looked a little surprised to see him. "Come on in." "Thanks." Albus came in and put his rucksack down on the table, then noticed there was only one set of textbooks. "Where's Malfoy?" "He said he wasn't feeling well." Rose sat back down, picked up her quill, then put it back down. "Honestly, he looked fine to me." Albus shrugged. "Well, if he says." He took out his neglected Potions essay and Muggle Studies report. "If you wouldn't mind, I wondered if you could read over--" "Albus, we should talk." His words and his good mood screeched to a halt. Albus closed his mouth, swallowed, then said, "About what?" "Your attitude." Rose pulled a lock of her auburn hair and ran her fingers through it. Albus knew that to be her nervous habit. "Specifically, toward Scorpius." "I don't have an attitude toward him." Though he spoke calmly, Rose picked up on the resentment in his tone. "You do." Rose's fingers closed with the hair still in between them as she spoke, "You call him Malfoy, even though you've been working with him for over a month. When we're together, you get so rude to him, and to me. And then you didn't come Tuesday--" "I was busy," Albus protested. Rose raised an eyebrow. "Really. And you didn't have the time to owl me." "No, I didn't." He fiercely opened his textbook to a random page and glared at it. "Why do I have to tell you what I do? You certainly don't do the same." "What does that mean?" "'Scorpius' this and 'Scorpius' that. All the time you're with him, he's like your shadow. He even touched your hair! I don't know, are you two dating?" "No!" Rose shouted. She took a deep breath to calm herself, then added, "We are not dating. Scorpius is my best friend." "Now that is hard to believe." Albus picked at the edge of the page and succeeded in ripping off a piece. "If he's your best friend, why isn't he at your birthday parties? And why hasn't anyone else said anything about this?" "Because Dad hates the Malfoys!" she said, her eyes suspiciously wet though she was still angrily clenching her hair. "And everyone else is smart enough--and nice enough--not to say anything about it!" His mouth didn't seem to want to close. Everyone else knows they're best friends? Best friends? Albus blinked several times, then put his hands on his temples. "I feel like a right arse." "You should," she spat. Rose pulled her hair over her eyes and rubbed at them. "You should feel like an arse, Al." Albus hated to see his family cry, and on top of that Rose was his most favorite cousin. He put his elbows on the table and rested his head on his palms. "How come I didn't know?" "You," she said thickly, "you were too busy one-upping and staying afloat in Slytherin, and you just wanted to play pranks on James, and you didn't pay any attention to me." Rose pushed her hair back and though her eyes were red, she didn't have tears anymore. "You became a Slytherin, so a Ravenclaw became my best friend." It was true; the only time he and Rose really saw each other was during the holidays, and only when the family got together. Albus had stopped hanging out with his favorite cousin after third year, in favor of developing his wit, mischief and contacts with Slytherin classmates. Albus bit his lip and said, "I'm sorry. What would it take for you to forgive me?" With a strangled laugh Rose punched him in the arm and said, "You goose. I already forgave you, by letting you study with us." She gave him a weak smile. "But treating me at Hogsmeade would be nice." "Then it's a date," Albus replied, rubbing the sore spot. He hesitated then asked, "Is... erm... Scorpius... going to come?" She picked up her quill and tapped it on the table. "Good try. Yes, Scorpius is going to Hogsmeade, and probably he will be in my company. But," she wagged the quill at him, "you do not have to treat him. He is not your date, I am." "Deal." Albus chuckled and said, "It's a little hard saying his name. Can't I just call him Scor or Mally or something easier?" "Don't you dare," cautioned Rose, "he hates nicknames. Like you, actually." "All right." As he pushed over his parchment he could feel his cheeks were warm. Probably from smiling too much. "Will you still look over this silly arse's essay?" ***
